name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: If it's not online, it's not accessible. Only 10 states have open, competitive online markets for #sportsbetting (NJ, PA, IN, WV, CO, TN, IA, IL, MI, VA) representing 23.5% of the US population. Otherwise it's retail only or lottery controlled which is not the same product

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: @Rex_Beyers Or just have open, mobile registration like the great state of New Jersey. In 2021, you shouldn’t have to sign up for anything in-person, including a sports betting account. name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: @jasonparadise The "Revenue". It doesn't matter if your LTV/CAC is 5-10+x. If you can't acquire enough customers, you can't cover your cost structure and that's why these media company sportsbook operators will never get to profitability

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: Let's go! Can't wait to see this studio come to life. Very excited to hear the stories and content coming from #BlueWire in this partnership. Sports, gaming and lifestyle will continue to converge

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: @jasonparadise Cost per Acquisition (CPA). That's what operators will pay an affiliate (i.e. media company) for a customer sent from their platform / channel

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: @martimj10 Insourcing is coming. They'll develop more capabilities internally (i.e. FanDuel moving away from GAN) or buy their or other suppliers (i.e. DraftKings acquisition of SBTech and Ballys acquisition of BetWorks)

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: @qualityperspec1 If you didn't crash for the Super Bowl, you didn't have enough customers....theScore tech is not better. It's like a restaurant, if there is a two hour wait, the food is generally better than if you can walk right in and the place is half empty

tweet: @jasontrost I agree. The leaders are trying to insource more and 'vertically integrate' to some extent. FD moving away from GAN to more proprietary tech, DK ultimately insourcing SBTech, BetMGM trying to leverage more from Entain tech. It's a marketing battle now, but product war long-term

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: @wedge_news Technology, software or other suppliers for iGaming and Sports betting ecosystem. We’re in the middle of a gold rush, I want to sell picks and shovels. Not every miner is going to find gold. That’s our thesis at #BettorCapital

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: 14) I'd rather not see the sports betting industry enthusiasm ultimately sour when this inevitable realization happens

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: 13) Nothing personal against FuboTV and theScore. There are good people at these companies trying their best to compete, but they're pushing a boulder uphill while investors think they're on the mountain top rolling down to a huge pot of gold

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: 12) In conclusion, media companies can't do it on their own. Fierce competition from operators with several billion dollars in their war chest will limit media businesses to low single digit market share at best and without a path to make their sports betting business profitable

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: 11) There seems to be a huge valuation gap on the perceived value of being a sportsbook. I firmly believe US Sports Betting & iGaming is a $50B TAM, but it doesn't really matter how big it is when you have <1% market share and can't cover your cost structure at maturity

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: 10) Yes, these media businesses have their core business and some level of tech, but nothing transformational. Media business will get bought for 2-4+x EV/Rev multiple, some value for tech/IP (if any) and some incremental value for brand depending on strength / relevance

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: 9) That's 200k new sports betting customers. Industry CPAs are $200-400+. Let's take the midpoint of $300 and that leads to $60M of value....seems to be a big gap between $60M and $2+B

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: 8) How much will someone pay for database? Let's analyze. If theScore has ~4M users, and eventually ~2+M users will be in legal betting jurisdictions, how much is that worth? Apply a very generous 10% conversion, as not all users will be bettors and some will use other platforms:

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: 7) Investors are drastically underestimated the costs to be a 'real' player in sports betting and the path to profitability, which doesn't exist for small players. With inflated valuations, there is no one coming to acquire the business and bail out shareholders eventually

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: 6) FanDuel likely acquired more new players in 10 states over the course of H2 2020 than a media company like FuboTV had on it's whole platform nationally after years of acquiring users

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: 5) No matter how big the media platform, unless you're Barstool Sports or ESPN, you're going to need to spend advertising $ on customer acquisition in a highly competitive market. FanDuel & DraftKings are acquiring hundreds of thousands of players per quarter in only 10 states

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: 4) Product and tech is going to be outsourced. Quasi-tech media companies like theScore are not building their sports betting engine. It's too hard and they are reliant on third parties who will be prioritizing bigger customers who may ultimately acquire them leaving a big gap

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: 3) To buy the market access to cover yourself in all the big states will costs hundreds of millions of dollars over the next decade. Companies with only a few hundred million on their balance sheet can't even afford to get in the game without diluting shareholders @RichLightShed

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: 2) You need three things to be successful in sports betting: 1: Market Access (licenses to operator), 2: Product / Tech, and 3: Brand / Marketing Engine. Media companies only have number 3 at some scale depending on the platform

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: 1) If Barstool Sports, with a growing audience of 66M monthly uniques, could conclude that 'going it alone' was not viable, how does any other media company in North America (outside of ESPN who is highly unlikely to try it) think they can build a sportsbook on their own?

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: A thread on the sports betting and the viability of media companies trying to become operators + how to maximize value for the long-term. I say this from experience as Head of Strategy @FanDuel and having sold @barstoolsports to $Penn in the most transformative txn in the space

name: Dave VanEgmond

It’s fools gold...there can’t be 15 winners in sports betting

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: @foodhallking @AndOneCapital @theScore @stoolpresidente @realwillmeade theScore to be a Top 3 operator in Canada: Yes: +150 No: -210 FanDuel & DraftKings have DFS databases in Canada, BetMGM will spend $100+M marketing in Ontario, and Barstool will be tapping into Spittin’ Chiclets audience. Bet365 already operating...it will be highly competitive

name: Dave VanEgmond

They will never be a top 10 player and won’t EVER make a profit in sports betting. I’m a huge bull on sports betting, but this isn’t the way to play it

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: @AndOneCapital @theScore @stoolpresidente @realwillmeade The floor? Barstool had 66M uniques and sold for $450M valuation. theScore is no where near the Barstool brand and that proven in market share data. TheScore is a distant player number 15-20 in the a highly competitive market who can’t make positive revenue let alone profit

name: Dave VanEgmond
tweet: @novy_williams @theScore I wonder how the bankers will pitch 5 straight quarters of negative NGR in the #sportsbetting business, since that’s the big growth story. It’s not FuboTV, but the company is a media business who is NOT a top 10 US sportsbook; and without scale there is no way to turn a profit

name: Dave VanEgmond
